Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project UTM S-STEM at the University of Tennessee Martin (UTM) will provide 35 scholarships for four years averaging $4,800 each year to academically promising students with financial need. Students will be incoming freshman and transfer students majoring in Chemistry, Engineering, Geology, Computer Science, and Mathematics. This project will provide the resources needed to recruit, support, and retain more students, including minorities and women, in STEM fields that will improve the nation's capacity for innovation and provide regional industry with needed STEM talent.

The project will recruit STEM students that have demonstrated financial need as well the desire and capability to major in an underrepresented STEM field: Chemistry, Mathematics, Engineering, Computer Science, or Geology. The UTM student body is largely first generation college students that come from rural areas and many come from economically challenged areas of Tennessee. The average family income of West Tennessee is lower than the US average and many of these students that come to UTM are under-prepared for STEM studies. A number of support mechanisms will be provided to aid these students. A major focus of the project will be the development of a STEM academy. This two week intensive academic course will be collaboratively taught each summer by all STEM disciplines and will review material from the previous year and introduce new material students will see in the upcoming year. The STEM academy will help to remedy areas where UTM S-STEM Scholars are struggling and give them a jump start on the upcoming year. It will serve as a method to reinforce material and concepts students learn in their classes and help them to retain this knowledge throughout their academic career. The project will also establish a learning community. This community will provide both scholarly and social activities to support the S-STEM students to persist in STEM and aid in career exploration. Activities will include monthly lunches with faculty, field trips to industrial sites and other areas specific to each of the disciplines involved, seminars, and involvement in service learning. Scholarship students will be guided in career exploration through exposure to opportunities in government, industry, research, academia, and education through field trips and speakers. Scholarship students will be encouraged to participate in research projects with mentoring faculty to broaden their STEM experiences and to apply to internships, summer experiences, and REU programs. This scholarship program will directly affect the success of the students involved as well as impact how science education is conducted in the future. The project will be evaluated through attitudinal surveys, graduation and retention rate data, STEM course performance, and questionnaires on all project components. Project results will be disseminated to the campus community and at national meetings focused on STEM education as data is evaluated yearly. S-STEM scholars will make YouTube videos to showcase their experiences throughout their time at UTM. The incorporation of the STEM Academy will serve as a model for all STEM and ideally other disciplines within the university and at other 4-year institutions with similar demographics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The S-STEM program at the University of Tennessee Martin had a significant impact on the scholars selected. The program also provided valuable insight to issues that many STEM majors face as when selecting these challenging majors. The S-STEM grant at UTM provided students with scholarships majoring in underrepresented STEM areas, Chemistry, Computer Science, Engineering, Geoscience, or Mathematics. The S-STEM program at UTM provided scholarships to 24 students. The program served as model as to how to recruit and retain these majors. In the five given majors, UTM has a 28.3% retention rate of students who persist in original STEM degree. The S-STEM scholar?s retention rate of students finishing in declared STEM major was 77.9%. Also, in these 5 majors only 51.9% graduate in any major at UTM, whereas S-STEM scholars had an 83.2% retention rate of students graduating, or will graduate within 6-years, from UTM. Of the 77.9% of S-STEM Scholars that have already graduated from UTM, all but one student are employed in a STEM field or are attending graduate school.

The intellectual gains afforded from implementing the S-STEM Scholars program at UTM was seen at multiple levels. Students in the program were able to work closely with STEM faculty at UTM. 94% of students completing the UTM S-STEM Scholars program completed a project, student employment, internship, or conducted research, increasing their knowledge which helped them to develop as STEM students and scholars. To aid students in the program students also met monthly with STEM advisors and participated in several social events to increase comradery and feeling of inclusiveness. Students also achieved intellectual gains through completing 40 hours of service learning. Students prepared and hosted hands-on activities for daycares in Martin, TN. They also volunteered time and effort on several occasions to help clean-up and organize the Coon Creek Science Center, a paleontology teaching and research facility operated by UTM.

The STEM Academy was developed and implemented to increase intellectual gains as well as have an impact on UTM and other similar institutions. Each summer the Scholars attended a two-week academic intensive course, collaboratively taught by all STEM disciplines, that reviewed material from the previous year and introduced material students would see in the upcoming year. The academy helped to remedy areas Scholars were struggling with and give them a jump start on the upcoming year. The Academy also exposed students to STEM majors and careers outside of their major. The STEM Academy has become a model of a program at UTM that could help to alleviate academic gaps that could hinder students from persisting in STEM majors.

To reinforce careers and opportunities in STEM, S-STEM Scholars also took field trips to industrial sites, universities, schools, and other areas specific to each of the disciplines represented. Scholars also attended monthly seminars given by STEM speakers in all STEM disciplines and participated in workshops focused on career exploration and development. S-STEM Scholars also worked closely with Career Planning and Development (CPAD) at UTM to help develop their resume and interviewing skills.
